813 I always should, It said, esteem Her well;
814 But never see her more: It bid Her feel
815 No future Pain for Me; but instant wed
816 A Lover more proportion'd to her Bed;
817 And quiet dedicate her remnant Life
818 To the just Duties of an humble Wife.
819 She read; and forth to Me She wildly ran,
820 To Me, the Ease of all her former Pain.
821 She kneel'd intreated, struggl'd, threaten'd, cry'd;
822 And with alternate Passion liv'd, and dy'd:
823 'Till now deny'd the Liberty to mourn,
824 And by rude Fury from my Presence torn,
[Page 462]
825 This only Object of my real Care,
826 Cut off from Hope, abandon'd to Despair,
827 In some few posting fatal Hours is hurl'd
828 From Wealth, from Pow'r, from Love, and from the World.
829 Here tell Me, if Thou dar'st, my conscious Soul,
830 What diff'rent Sorrows did within Thee roll:
831 What Pangs, what Fires, what Racks didst Thou sustain,
832 What sad Vicissitudes of smarting Pain?
833 How oft from Pomp and State did I remove,
834 To feed Despair, and cherish hopeless Love?
835 How oft, all Day, recall'd I Abra's Charms,
836 Her Beauties press'd, and panting in my Arms?
837 How oft, with Sighs, view'd every Female Face,
838 Where mimic Fancy might her Likeness trace?
839 How oft desir'd to fly from Israel's Throne,
840 And live in Shades with Her and Love alone?
841 How oft, all Night, pursu'd Her in my Dreams,
842 O'er flow'ry Vallies, and thro' Crystal Streams;
843 And waking, view'd with Grief the rising Sun,
844 And fondly mourn'd the dear Delusion gone?
845 When thus the gather'd Storms of wretched Love
846 In my swoln Bosom, with long War had strove;
847 At length they broke their Bounds: at length their Force
848 Bore down whatever met it's stronger Course:
849 Lay'd all the Civil Bonds of Manhood waste;
850 And scatter'd Ruin as the Torrent past.
[Page 463]
851 So from the Hills, whose hollow Caves contain
852 The congregated Snow, and swelling Rain;
853 'Till the full Stores their antient Bounds disdain;
854 Precipitate the furious Torrent flows:
855 In vain would Speed avoid, or Strength oppose:
856 Towns, Forests, Herds, and Men promiscuous drown'd,
857 With one great Death deform the dreary Ground;
858 The echo'd Woes from distant Rocks resound.
859 And now what impious Ways my Wishes took;
860 How they the Monarch, and the Man forsook;
861 And how I follow'd an abandon'd Will,
862 Thro' crooked Paths, and sad Retreats of Ill;
863 How Judah's Daughters now, now foreign Slaves,
864 By turns my prostituted Bed receives.
865 Thro' Tribes of Women how I loosely rang'd
866 Impatient; lik'd To-night, To-morrow chang'd;
867 And by the Instinct of capricious Lust,
868 Enjoy'd, disdain'd, was grateful, or unjust:
869 O, be these Scenes from human Eyes conceal'd,
870 In Clouds of decent Silence justly veil'd!
871 O, be the wanton Images convey'd
872 To black Oblivion, and eternal Shade!
873 Or let their sad Epitome alone,
874 And outward Lines to future Age be known,
875 Enough to propagate the sure Belief,
876 That Vice engenders Shame; and Folly broods o'er Grief.
[Page 464]
877 Bury'd in Sloth, and lost in Ease I lay:
878 The Night I revell'd; and I slept the Day.
879 New Heaps of Fewel damp'd my kindling Fires;
880 And daily Change extinguish'd young Desires.
881 By its own Force destroy'd, Fruition ceas'd;
882 And always weary'd, I was never pleas'd.
883 No longer now does my neglected Mind
884 It's wonted Stores, and old Ideas find.
885 Fix'd Judgment there no longer does abide,
886 To take the True, or set the False aside.
887 No longer does swift Mem'ry trace the Cells,
888 Where springing Wit, or young Invention dwells.
889 Frequent Debauch to Habitude prevails:
890 Patience of Toil, and Love of Virtue fails.
891 By sad Degrees impair'd my Vigor dyes;
892 Till I Command no longer ev'n in Vice.
893 The Women on my Dotage build their Sway:
894 They ask; I grant: They threaten; I obey.
895 In Regal Garments now I gravely stride,
896 Aw'd by the Persian Dam'sel's haughty Pride.
897 Now with the looser Syrian dance, and sing,
898 In Robes tuck'd up, opprobrious to the King.
899 Charm'd by their Eyes, their Manners I acquire;
900 And shape my Foolishness to their Desire.
901 Seduc'd and aw'd by the Philistine Dame,
902 At Dagon's Shrine I kindle impious Flame.
[Page 465]
903 With the Chaldean's Charms her Rites prevail;
904 And curling Frankincense ascends to Baal.
905 To each new Harlot I new Altars dress;
906 And serve Her God, whose Person I caress.
907 Where, my deluded Sense, was Reason flown?
908 Where the high Majesty of David's Throne?
909 Where all the Maxims of Eternal Truth,
910 With which the Living GOD inform'd my Youth?
911 When with the lewd Egyptian I Adore
912 Vain Idols, Deities that ne'er before
913 In Israel's Land had fix'd their dire Abodes,
914 Beastly Divinities, and Droves of Gods:
915 Osiris, Apis, Pow'rs that chew the Cud,
916 And Dog Anubis, Flatt'rer for his Food:
917 When in the Woody Hill's forbidden Shade
918 I carv'd the Marble, and invok'd it's Aid:
919 When in the Fens to Snakes and Flies, with Zeal
920 Unworthy human Thought, I prostrate fell;
921 To Shrubs and Plants my vile Devotion paid;
922 And set the bearded Leek, to which I pray'd:
923 When to all Beings Sacred Rites were giv'n;
924 Forgot the Arbiter of Earth and Heav'n.
925 Thro' these sad Shades, this Chaos in my Soul,
926 Some Seeds of Light at length began to roll.
927 The rising Motion of an Infant Ray
928 Shot glimm'ring thro' the Cloud, and promis'd Day.
929 And now one Moment able to reflect,
930 I found the King abandon'd to Neglect,
931 Seen without Awe, and serv'd without Respect.
[Page 466]
932 I found my Subjects amicably joyn,
933 To lessen their Defects, by citing Mine.
934 The Priest with Pity pray'd for David's Race;
935 And left his Text, to dwell on my Disgrace.
936 The Father, whilst he warn'd his erring Son,
937 The sad Examples which He ought to shun,
938 Describ'd, and only nam'd not, Solomon.
939 Each Bard, each Sire did to his Pupil sing,
940 A Wise Child better than a Foolish King.
941 Into My self my Reason's Eye I turn'd;
942 And as I much reflected, much I mourn'd.
943 A Mighty King I am, an Earthly God:
944 Nations obey my Word, and wait my Nod.
945 I raise or sink, imprison or set free;
946 And Life or Death depends on My Decree.
947 Fond the Idea, and the Thought is vain:
948 O'er Judah's King ten thousand Tyrants reign.
949 Legions of Lust, and various Pow'rs of Ill
950 Insult the Master's Tributary Will:
951 And He, from whom the Nations should receive
952 Justice, and Freedom, lyes Himself a Slave,
953 Tortur'd by cruel Change of wild Desires,
954 Lash'd by mad Rage, and scorch'd by brutal Fires.
955 O Reason! once again to Thee I call:
956 Accept my Sorrow, and retrieve my Fall.
957 Wisdom, Thou say'st, from Heav'n receiv'd her Birth;
958 Her Beams transmitted to the subject Earth.
959 Yet this great Empress of the human Soul
960 Does only with imagin'd Pow'r controul;
[Page 467]
961 If restless Passion by Rebellious Sway
962 Compells the weak Usurper to obey.
963 O troubled, weak, and Coward, as thou art!
964 Without thy poor Advice the lab'ring Heart
965 To worse Extremes with swifter Steps would run,
966 Not sav'd by Virtue, yet by Vice undone.
967 Oft have I said, the Praise of doing well
968 Is to the Ear, as Oyntment to the Smell.
969 Now if some Flies perchance, however small,
970 Into the Alabaster Urn should fall;
971 The Odors of the Sweets inclos'd would dye;
972 And Stench corrupt (sad Change!) their Place supply.
973 So the least Faults, if mix'd with fairest Deed,
974 Of future Ill become the fatal Seed:
975 Into the Balm of purest Virtue cast,
976 Annoy all Life with one contagious Blast.
977 Lost Solomon! pursue this Thought no more:
978 Of thy past Errors recollect the Store:
979 And silent weep, that while the Deathless Muse
980 Shall sing the Just; shall o'er their Head diffuse
981 Perfumes with lavish Hand; She shall proclaim
982 Thy Crimes alone; and to Thy evil Fame
983 Impartial, scatter Damps, and Poysons on thy Name.
984 Awaking therefore, as who long had dream'd,
985 Much of my Women, and their Gods asham'd,
986 From this Abyss of exemplary Vice
987 Resolv'd, as Time might aid my Thought, to rise;
[Page 468]
988 Again I bid the mournful Goddess write
989 The fond Pursuit of fugitive Delight:
990 Bid her exalt her melancholy Wing,
991 And rais'd from Earth, and sav'd from Passion, sing
992 Of human Hope by cross Event destroy'd,
993 Of useless Wealth, and Greatness unenjoy'd,
994 Of Lust and Love, with their fantastic Train,
995 Their Wishes, Smiles, and Looks deceitful all, and vain.
[Page]

POWER; THE THIRD BOOK.

[Page][Page]

The ARGUMENT.

Solomon considers Man through the several Stages and Conditions of Life; and concludes in general, that We are all Miserable. He reflects more particularly upon the Trouble and Uncertainty of Greatness and Power; gives some Instances thereof from Adam down to Himself; and still concludes that All is Vanity. He reasons again upon Life, Death, and a future Being; finds Human Wisdom too imperfect to resolve his Doubts; has Recourse to Religion; is informed by an Angel, what shall happen to Himself, his Family, and his Kingdom, 'till the Redemption of Israel: and, upon the whole, resolves to submit his Enquiries and Anxieties to the Will of his Creator.

[Page]

TEXTS chiefly alluded to in this Book.

Or ever the Silver Cord be loosed, or the golden Bowl be broken, or the Pitcher be broken at the Fountain, or the Wheel broken at the Cistern. Ecclesiastes, Chap. XII. Vers. 6.

The Sun ariseth, and the Sun goeth down, and hasteth to his Place where He arose. Ecclesiastes, Chap. I. Vers. 5.

The Wind goeth towards the South, and turneth about unto the North. It whirleth about continually; and the Wind returneth again according to his Circuit. Vers. 6.

All the Rivers run into the Sea: yet the Sea is not full. Unto the Place from whence the Rivers come, thither they return again. Vers. 7.

Then shall the Dust return to the Earth, as it was: and the Spirit shall return unto God who gave it. Ecclesiastes, Chap. XII. Vers. 7.

Now when Solomon had made an End of Praying, the Fire came down from Heaven, and consumed the Burnt-offering, and the Sacrifices; and the Glory of the Lord filled the House. II Chronicles, Chap. VII. Vers. I.

By the Rivers of Babylon, there We sat down; Yea We wept, when We remembred Sion &c. Psalm CXXXVII. Vers. I.

I said of Laughter, it is mad; and of Mirth, what doeth it? Ecclesiastes, Chap. II. Vers. 2.

‚Äî No Man can find out the Work that God maketh, from the Beginning to the End. Ecclesiastes, Chap. III. Vers. II.

Whatsoever God doeth, it shall be for ever: nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it: and God doeth it, that Men should fear before Him. Vers. 14.

Let us hear the Conclusion of the whole Matter; Fear God, and keep his Commandments; for this is the whole Duty of Man. Ecclesiastes, Chap. XII. Verse. 13.

POWER; THE THIRD BOOK.
1 Come then, my Soul: I call Thee by that Name,
2 Thou busie Thing, from whence I know I am:
3 For knowing that I am, I know Thou art;
4 Since That must needs exist, which can impart.
5 But how Thou cam'st to be, or whence Thy Spring:
6 For various of Thee Priests and Poets sing.
[Page 474]
7 Hear'st Thou submissive, but a lowly Birth,
8 Some sep'rate Particles of finer Earth,
9 A plain Effect, which Nature must beget,
10 As Motion orders, and as Atoms meet;
11 Companion of the Body's Good or Ill,
12 From Force of Instinct more than Choice of Will;
13 Conscious of Fear or Valor, Joy or Pain,
14 As the wild Courses of the Blood ordain;
15 Who as Degrees of Heat and Cold prevail,
16 In Youth dost flourish, and with Age shalt fail;
17 'Till mingl'd with thy Part'ner's latest Breath
18 Thou fly'st, dissolv'd in Air, and lost in Death.
19 Or if Thy great Existence would aspire
20 To Causes more sublime; of Heav'nly Fire
21 Wer't Thou a Spark struck off, a sep'rate Ray,
22 Ordain'd to mingle with Terrestrial Clay;
23 With it condemn'd for certain Years to dwell,
24 To grieve it's Frailties, and it's Pains to feel;
25 To teach it Good and Ill, Disgrace or Fame;
26 Pale it with Rage, or redden it with Shame:
27 To guide it's Actions with informing Care,
28 In Peace to Judge, to Conquer in the War;
29 Render it Agile, Witty, Valiant, Sage,
30 As fits the various Course of human Age;
31 Till as the Earthly Part decays and falls,
32 The Captive breaks Her Prison's mould'ring Walls;
33 Hovers a-while upon the sad Remains,
34 Which now the Pile, or Sepulchre contains;
[Page 475]
35 And thence with Liberty unbounded flies,
36 Impatient to regain Her native Skies.
37 Whate'er Thou art, where-e'er ordain'd to go:
38 (Points which We rather may dispute, than know)
39 Come on, Thou little Inmate of this Breast,
40 Which for Thy Sake from Passions I divest:
41 For these, Thou say'st, raise all the stormy Strife,
42 Which hinder Thy Repose, and trouble Life.
43 Be the fair Level of Thy Actions laid,
44 As Temp'rance wills, and Prudence may perswade;
45 Be Thy Affections undisturb'd and clear,
46 Guided to what may Great or Good appear;
47 And try if Life be worth the Liver's Care.
48 Amass'd in Man there justly is beheld
49 What thro' the whole Creation has excell'd:
50 The Life and Growth of Plants, of Beasts the Sense,
51 The Angel's Forecast and Intelligence:
52 Say from these glorious Seeds what Harvest flows;
53 Recount our Blessings, and compare our Woes.
54 In it's true Light let clearest Reason see
55 The Man dragg'd out to Act, and forc'd to Be;
56 Helpless and Naked on a Woman's Knees
57 To be expos'd or rear'd as She may please;
58 Feel her Neglect, and pine from her Disease.
59 His tender Eye by too direct a Ray
60 Wounded, and flying from unpractis'd Day;
61 His Heart assaulted by invading Air,
62 And beating fervent to the vital War;
[Page 476]
63 To his Young Sense how various Forms appear;
64 That strike his Wonder, and excite his Fear?
65 By his Distortions he reveals his Pains;
66 He by his Tears, and by his Sighs complains;
67 'Till Time and Use assist the Infant Wretch,
68 By broken Words, and Rudiments of Speech,
69 His Wants in plainer Characters to show,
70 And paint more perfect Figures of his Woe.
71 Condemn'd to sacrifice his childish Years
72 To babling Ign'rance, and to empty Fears;
73 To pass the riper Period of his Age,
74 Acting his Part upon a crowded Stage;
75 To lasting Toils expos'd, and endless Cares,
76 To open Dangers, and to secret Snares;
77 To Malice which the vengeful Foe intends,
78 And the more dangerous Love of seeming Friends.
79 His Deeds examin'd by the People's Will,
80 Prone to forget the Good, and blame the Ill:
81 Or sadly censur'd in their curs'd Debate,
82 Who in the Scorner's, or the Judge's Seat
83 Dare to condemn the Virtue which They hate.
84 Or would he rather leave this frantic Scene;
85 And Trees and Beasts prefer to Courts and Men?
86 In the remotest Wood and lonely Grott
87 Certain to meet that worst of Evils, Thought;
88 Diff'rent Ideas to his Mem'ry brought:
89 Some intricate, as are the pathless Woods;
90 Impetuous some, as the descending Floods:
91 With anxious Doubts, with raging Passions torn,
92 No sweet Companion near with whom to mourn;
[Page 477]
93 He hears the Echoing Rock return his Sighs;
94 And from himself the frighted Hermit flies.
95 Thus, thro' what Path soe'er of Life We rove,
96 Rage companies our Hate, and Grief our Love:
97 Vex'd with the present Moment's heavy Gloom,
98 Why seek We Brightness from the Years to come?
99 Disturb'd and broken like a sick Man's Sleep,
100 Our troubl'd Thoughts to distant Prospects leap;
101 Desirous still what flies us to o'ertake:
102 For Hope is but the Dream of Those that wake:
103 But looking back, We see the dreadful Train
104 Of Woes, a-new which were We to sustain,
105 We should refuse to tread the Path again.
106 Still adding Grief, still counting from the first;
107 Judging the latest Evils still the worst;
108 And sadly finding each progressive Hour
109 Heighten their Number, and augment their Pow'r;
110 Till by one countless Sum of Woes opprest,
111 Hoary with Cares, and Ignorant of Rest,
112 We find the vital Springs relax'd and worn:
113 Compell'd our common Impotence to mourn,
114 Thus, thro' the Round of Age, to Childhood We return;
115 Reflecting find, that naked from the Womb
116 We yesterday came forth; that in the Tomb
117 Naked again We must To-morrow lye,
118 Born to lament, to labor, and to dye.
119 Pass We the Ills, which each Man feels or dreads,
120 The Weight or fall'n, or hanging o'er our Heads;
[Page 478]
121 The Bear, The Lyon, Terrors of the Plain,
122 The Sheepfold scatter'd, and the Shepherd slain;
123 The frequent Errors of the pathless Wood,
124 The giddy Precipice, and the dang'rous Flood:
125 The noisom Pest'lence, that in open War
126 Terrible, marches thro' the Mid-day Air,
127 And scatters Death; the Arrow that by Night
128 Cuts the dank Mist, and fatal wings it's Flight;
129 The billowing Snow, and Violence of the Show'r,
130 That from the Hills disperse their dreadful Store,
131 And o'er the Vales collected Ruin pour;
132 The Worm that gnaws the ripening Fruit, sad Guest,
133 Canker or Locust hurtful to infest
134 The Blade; while Husks elude the Tiller's Care,
135 And Eminence of Want distinguishes the Year.
136 Pass we the slow Disease, and subtil Pain,
137 Which our weak Frame is destin'd to sustain;
138 The cruel Stone, with congregated War
139 Tearing his bloody Way; the cold Catarrh,
140 With frequent Impulse, and continu'd Strife,
141 Weak'ning the wasted Seats of irksom Life;
142 The Gout's fierce Rack, the burning Feaver's Rage,
143 The sad Experience of Decay; and Age,
144 Her self the soarest Ill; while Death, and Ease,
145 Oft and in vain invok'd, or to appease,
146 Or end the Grief, with hasty Wings receed
147 From the vext Patient, and the sickly Bed.
148 Nought shall it profit, that the charming Fair,
149 Angelic, softest Work of Heav'n, draws near
[Page 479]
150 To the cold shaking paralytic Hand,
151 Senseless of Beauty's Touch, or Love's Command,
152 Nor longer apt, or able to fulfill
153 The Dictates of it's feeble Master's Will.
154 Nought shall the Psaltry, and the Harp avail,
155 The pleasing Song, or well repeated Tale,
156 When the quick Spirits their warm March forbear;
157 And numbing Coldness has unbrac'd the Ear.
158 The verdant Rising of the flow'ry Hill,
159 The Vale enamell'd, and the Crystal Rill,
160 The Ocean rolling, and the shelly Shoar,
161 Beautiful Objects, shall delight no more;
162 When the lax'd Sinews of the weaken'd Eye
163 In wat'ry Damps, or dim Suffusion lye.
164 Day follows Night; the Clouds return again
165 After the falling of the later Rain:
166 But to the Aged-blind shall ne'er return
167 Grateful Vicissitude: He still must mourn
168 The Sun, and Moon, and ev'ry Starry Light
169 Eclips'd to Him, and lost in everlasting Night.
170 Behold where Age's wretched Victim lies:
171 See his Head trembling, and his half-clos'd Eyes:
172 Frequent for Breath his panting Bosom heaves:
173 To broken Sleeps his remnant Sense He gives;
174 And only by his Pains, awaking finds He Lives.
175 Loos'd by devouring Time the Silver Cord
176 Dissever'd lies: unhonor'd from the Board
[Page 480]
177 The Crystal Urn, when broken, is thrown by;
178 And apter Utensils their Place supply.
179 These Things and Thou must share One equal Lot;
180 Dye and be lost, corrupt and be forgot;
181 While still another, and another Race
182 Shall now supply, and now give up the Place.
183 From Earth all came, to Earth must all return;
184 Frail as the Cord, and brittle as the Urn.
185 But be the Terror of these Ills suppress'd:
186 And view We Man with Health and Vigor blest.
187 Home He returns with the declining Sun,
188 His destin'd Task of Labor hardly done;
189 Goes forth again with the ascending Ray,
190 Again his Travel for his Bread to pay,
191 And find the Ill sufficient to the Day.
192 Hap'ly at Night He does with Horror shun
193 A widow'd Daughter, or a dying Son:
194 His Neighbor's Off-spring He To-morrow sees;
195 And doubly feels his Want in their Increase:
196 The next Day, and the next he must attend
197 His Foe triumphant, or his buried Friend.
198 In ev'ry Act and Turn of Life he feels
199 Public Calamities, or Household Ills:
200 The due Reward to just Desert refus'd:
201 The Trust betray'd, the Nuptial Bed abus'd:
202 The Judge corrupt, the long depending Cause,
203 And doubtful Issue of misconstru'd Laws:
204 The crafty Turns of a dishonest State,
205 And violent Will of the wrong-doing Great:
[Page 481]
206 The Venom'd Tongue injurious to his Fame,
207 Which nor can Wisdom shun, nor fair Advice reclaim.
208 Esteem We these, my Friends, Event and Chance,
209 Produc'd as Atoms form their flutt'ring Dance?
210 Or higher yet their Essence may We draw
211 From destin'd Order, and Eternal Law?
212 Again, my Muse, the cruel Doubt repeat:
213 Spring they, I say, from Accident, or Fate?
214 Yet such, We find, they are, as can controll
215 The servile Actions of our wav'ring Soul;
216 Can fright, can alter, or can chain the Will;
217 Their Ills all built on Life, that fundamental Ill.
218 O fatal Search! in which the lab'ring Mind,
219 Still press'd with Weight of Woe, still hopes to find
220 A Shadow of Delight, a Dream of Peace,
221 From Years of Pain, one Moment of Release;
222 Hoping at least She may Her self deceive,
223 Against Experience willing to believe,
224 Desirous to rejoice, condemn'd to grieve.
225 Happy the Mortal Man, who now at last
226 Has thro' this doleful Vale of Mis'ry past;
227 Who to his destin'd Stage has carry'd on
228 The tedious Load, and laid his Burden down;
229 Whom the cut Brass, or wounded Marble shows
230 Victor o'er Life, and all Her Train of Woes.
231 He happyer yet, who privileg'd by Fate
232 To shorter Labor, and a lighter Weight,
[Page 482]
233 Receiv'd but Yesterday the Gift of Breath,
234 Order'd To-morrow to return to Death.
235 But O! beyond Description happyest He,
236 Who ne'er must roll on Life's tumultuous Sea;
237 Who with bless'd Freedom from the gen'ral Doom
238 Exempt, must never force the teeming Womb,
239 Nor see the Sun, nor sink into the Tomb.
240 Who breaths, must suffer; and who thinks, must mourn;
241 And He alone is bless'd, who ne'er was born.
242 "Yet in thy turn, Thou frowning Preacher, hear:
243 " Are not these general Maxims too severe?
244 "Say: cannot Pow'r secure it's Owner's Bliss?
245 " And is not Wealth the potent Sire of Peace?
246 "Are Victors bless'd with Fame, or Kings with Ease?
247 I tell Thee, Life is but one common Care;
248 And Man was born to suffer, and to fear.
249 "But is no Rank, no Station, no Degree
250 " From this contagious Taint of Sorrow free?
251 None, Mortal, None: Yet in a bolder Strain
252 Let Me this melancholy Truth maintain:
253 But hence, Ye Worldly, and Prophane, retire:
254 For I adapt my Voice, and raise my Lyre
255 To Notions not by Vulgar Ear receiv'd:
256 Ye still must covet Life, and be deceiv'd:
[Page 483]
257 Your very Fear of Death shall make Ye try
258 To catch the Shade of Immortality;
259 Wishing on Earth to linger, and to save
260 Part of it's Prey from the devouring Grave;
261 To those who may survive Ye, to bequeath
262 Something entire, in spight of Time, and Death;
263 A fancy'd Kind of Being to retrieve,
264 And in a Book, or from a Building live.
265 False Hope! vain Labor! let some Ages fly:
266 The Dome shall moulder, and the Volume dye:
267 Wretches, still taught, still will Ye think it strange,
268 That all the Parts of this great Fabric change;
269 Quit their old Station, and Prim√¶val Frame;
270 And lose their Shape, their Essence, and their Name?
271 Reduce the Song: our Hopes, our Joys are vain:
272 Our Lot is Sorrow; and Our Portion Pain.
273 What Pause from Woe, what Hopes of Comfort bring
274 The Name of Wise or Great, of Judge or King?
275 What is a King? A Man condemn'd to bear
276 The public Burden of the Nation's Care;
277 Now crown'd some angry Faction to appease;
278 Now falls a Victim to the People's Ease:
279 From the first blooming of his ill-taught Youth,
280 Nourish'd in Flatt'ry, and estrang'd from Truth:
281 At Home surrounded by a servile Crowd,
282 Prompt to abuse, and in Detraction loud:
283 Abroad begirt with Men, and Swords, and Spears;
284 His very State acknowledging his Fears:
[Page 484]
285 Marching amidst a thousand Guards, He shows
286 His secret Terror of a thousand Foes;
287 In War however Prudent, Great, or Brave,
288 To blind Events, and fickle Chance a Slave:
289 Seeking to settle what for ever flies;
290 Sure of the Toil, uncertain of the Prize.
291 But He returns with Conquest on his Brow;
292 Brings up the Triumph, and absolves the Vow:
293 The Captive Generals to his Carr are ty'd:
294 The Joyful Citizens tumultuous Tyde
295 Echoing his Glory, gratify his Pride.
296 What is this Triumph? Madness, Shouts, and Noise,
297 One great Collection of the People's Voice.
298 The Wretches he brings back, in Chains relate,
299 What may To-morrow be the Victor's Fate.
300 The Spoils and Trophies born before Him, show
301 National Loss, and Epidemic Woe,
302 Various Distress, which He and His may know.
303 Does He not mourn the valiant Thousands slain;
304 The Heroes, once the Glory of the Plain,
305 Left in the Conflict of the Fatal Day,
306 Or the Wolve's Portion, or the Vulture's Prey?
307 Does He not weep the Lawrel, which he wears,
308 Wet with the Soldier's Blood, and Widow's Tears?
309 See, where He comes, the Darling of the War!
310 See Millions crowding round the gilded Car!
311 In the vast Joys of this Ecstatic Hour,
312 And full Fruition of successful Pow'r,
[Page 485]
313 One Moment and one Thought might let Him scan
314 The various Turns of Life, and fickle State of Man.
315 Are the dire Images of sad Distrust,
316 And Popular Change, obscur'd a-mid the Dust,
317 That rises from the Victor's rapid Wheel?
318 Can the loud Clarion, or shrill Fife repel
319 The inward Cries of Care? can Nature's Voice
320 Plaintive be drown'd, or lessen'd in the Noise;
321 Tho' Shouts as Thunder loud afflict the Air;
322 Stun the Birds now releas'd, and shake the Iv'ry Chair?
323 Yon' Crowd (He might reflect) yon' joyful Crowd,
324 Pleas'd with my Honors, in my Praises loud,
325 (Should fleeting Vict'ry to the Vanquish'd go;
326 Should She depress my Arms, and raise the Foe;)
327 Would for That Foe with equal Ardor wait
328 At the high Palace, or the crowded Gate;
329 With restless Rage would pull my Statues down;
330 And cast the Brass a-new to His Renown.
331 O impotent Desire of Worldly Sway!
332 That I, who make the Triumph of To-day,
333 May of To-morrow's Pomp one Part appear,
334 Ghastly with Wounds, and lifeless on the Bier!
335 Then (Vileness of Mankind!) then of all These,
336 Whom my dilated Eye with Labor sees,
337 Would one, alas! repeat Me Good, or Great?
338 Wash my pale Body, or bewail my Fate?
[Page 486]
339 Or, march'd I chain'd behind the Hostile Carr,
340 The Victor's Pastime, and the Sport of War;
341 Would One, would One his pitying Sorrow lend,
342 Or be so poor, to own He was my Friend?
343 Avails it then, O Reason, to be Wise?
344 To see this cruel Scene with quicker Eyes?
345 To know with more Distinction to complain,
346 And have superior Sense in feeling Pain?
347 Let us revolve that Roll with strictest Eye,
348 Where safe from Time distinguish'd Actions lye;
349 And judge if Greatness be exempt from Pain,
350 Or Pleasure ever may with Pow'r remain.
351 Adam, great Type, for whom the World was made,
352 The fairest Blessing to his Arms convey'd,
353 A charming Wife; and Air, and Sea, and Land,
354 And all that move therein, to his Command
355 Render'd obedient: say, my Pensive Muse,
356 What did these golden Promises produce?
357 Scarce tasting Life, He was of Joy bereav'd:
358 One Day, I think, in Paradise He liv'd;
359 Destin'd the next His Journey to pursue,
360 Where wounding Thorns, and cursed Thistles grew.
361 E'er yet He earns his Bread, a-down his Brow,
362 Inclin'd to Earth, his lab'ring Sweat must flow:
363 His Limbs must ake, with daily Toils oppress'd;
364 E'er long-wish'd Night brings necessary Rest:
[Page 487]
365 Still viewing with Regret his Darling Eve,
366 He for Her Follies, and His own must grieve.
367 Bewailing still a-fresh their hapless Choice;
368 His Ear oft frighted with the imag'd Voice
369 Of Heav'n, when first it thunder'd; oft his View
370 A-ghast, as when the Infant Light'ning flew;
371 And the stern Cherub stop'd the fatal Road,
372 Arm'd with the Flames of an Avenging GOD.
373 His Younger Son on the polluted Ground,
374 First Fruit of Death, lies Plaintif of a Wound
375 Giv'n by a Brother's Hand: His Eldest Birth
376 Flies, mark'd by Heav'n, a Fugitive o'er Earth.
377 Yet why these Sorrows heap'd upon the Sire,
378 Becomes nor Man, nor Angel to enquire.
379 Each Age sinn'd on; and Guilt advanc'd with Time:
380 The Son still added to the Father's Crime;
381 'Till God arose, and great in Anger said:
382 Lo! it repenteth Me, that Man was made.
383 Withdraw thy Light, Thou Sun! be dark, Ye Skies!
384 And from your deep Abyss, Ye Waters, rise!
385 The frighted Angels heard th'Almighty Lord;
386 And o'er the Earth from wrathful Viols pour'd
387 Tempests and Storm, obedient to His Word.
388 Mean time, His Providence to Noah gave
389 The Guard of All, that He design'd to save.
390 Exempt from general Doom the Patriarch stood;
391 Contemn'd the Waves, and triumph'd o'er the Flood.
[Page 488]
392 The Winds fall silent; and the Waves decrease:
393 The Dove brings Quiet, and the Olive Peace:
394 Yet still His Heart does inward Sorrow feel,
395 Which Faith alone forbids Him to reveal.
396 If on the backward World his Views are cast;
397 'Tis Death diffus'd, and universal Waste.
398 Present (sad Prospect!) can He Ought descry,
399 But (what affects his melancholy Eye)
400 The Beauties of the Antient Fabric lost,
401 In Chains of craggy Hill, or Lengths of dreary Coast?
402 While to high Heav'n his pious Breathings turn'd,
403 Weeping He hop'd, and Sacrificing mourn'd;
404 When of GOD's Image only Eight He found
405 Snatch'd from the Wat'ry Grave, and sav'd from Nations drown'd;
406 And of three Sons, the future Hopes of Earth,
407 The Seed, whence Empires must receive their Birth,
408 One He foresees excluded Heav'nly Grace,
409 And mark'd with Curses, fatal to his Race.
410 Abraham, Potent Prince, the Friend of GOD,
411 Of Human Ills must bear the destin'd Load;
412 By Blood and Battles must his Pow'r maintain,
413 And slay the Monarchs, e'er He rules the Plain;
414 Must deal just Portions of a servile Life
415 To a proud handmaid, and a peevish Wife;
416 Must with the Mother leave the weeping Son,
417 In Want to wander, and in Wilds to groan;
418 Must take his other Child, his Age's Hope
419 To trembling Moriam's melancholy Top,
[Page 489]
420 Order'd to drench his Knife in filial Blood;
421 Destroy his Heir, or disobey his GOD.
422 Moses beheld that GOD; but how beheld?
423 The Deity in radiant Beams conceal'd,
424 And clouded in a deep Abyss of Light;
425 While present, too severe for Human Sight,
426 Nor staying longer than one swift-wing'd Night.
427 The following Days, and Months, and Years decreed
428 To fierce Encounter, and to toilsome Deed.
429 His Youth with Wants and Hardships must engage:
430 Plots and Rebellions must disturb his Age.
431 Some Corah still arose, some Rebel Slave,
432 Prompter to sink the State, than He to save:
433 And Israel did his Rage so far provoke,
434 That what the God-head wrote, the Prophet broke.
435 His Voice scarce heard, his Dictates scarce believ'd,
436 In Camps, in Arms, in Pilgrimage, He liv'd;
437 And dy'd obedient to severest Law,
438 Forbid to tread the promis'd Land, He saw.
439 My Father's Life was one long Line of Care,
440 A Scene of Danger, and a State of War.
441 Alarm'd, expos'd, his Childhood must engage
442 The Bear's rough Gripe, and foaming Lion's Rage.
443 By various Turns his threaten'd Youth must fear
444 Goliah's lifted Sword, and Saul's emitted Spear.
445 Forlorn He must, and persecuted fly;
446 Climb the steep Mountain, in the Cavern lye;
447 And often ask, and be refus'd to dye.
[Page 490]
448 For ever, from His manly Toils, are known
449 The Weight of Pow'r, and Anguish of a Crown.
450 What Tongue can speak the restless Monarch's Woes;
451 When GOD, and Nathan were declar'd his Foes?
452 When ev'ry Object his Offence revil'd,
453 The Husband murder'd, and the Wife defil'd,
454 The Parent's Sins impress'd upon the dying Child?
455 What Heart can think the Grief which He sustain'd;
456 When the King's Crime brought Vengeance on the Land;
457 And the inexorable Prophet's Voice
458 Gave Famine, Plague, or War; and bid him fix his Choice?
459 He dy'd; and Oh! may no Reflection shed
460 It's poys'nous Venom on the Royal Dead:
461 Yet the unwilling Truth must be express'd;
462 Which long has labor'd in this pensive Breast:
463 Dying He added to my Weight of Care:
464 He made Me to his Crimes undoubted Heir:
465 Left his unfinish'd Murder to his Son,
466 And Joab's Blood intail'd on Judah's Crown.
467 Young as I was, I hasted to fulfill
468 The cruel Dictates of My Parent's Will.
469 Of his fair Deeds a distant View I took;
470 But turn'd the Tube upon his Faults to look;
471 Forgot his Youth, spent in his Country's Cause,
472 His Care of Right, his Rev'rence to the Laws:
473 But could with Joy his Years of Folly trace,
474 Broken and old in Bathsheba's Embrace;
[Page 491]
475 Could follow Him, where e'er He stray'd from Good,
476 And cite his sad Example; whilst I trod
477 Paths open to Deceit, and track'd with Blood.
478 Soon docile to the secret Acts of Ill,
479 With Smiles I could betray, with Temper kill:
480 Soon in a Brother could a Rival view;
481 Watch all his Acts, and all his Ways pursue.
482 In vain for Life He to the Altar fled:
483 Ambition and Revenge have certain Speed.
484 Ev'n there, My Soul, ev'n there He should have fell;
485 But that my Interest did my Rage conceal.
486 Doubling my Crime, I promise, and deceive;
487 Purpose to slay, whilst swearing to forgive.
488 Treaties, Perswasions, Sighs, and Tears are vain:
489 With a mean Lie curs'd Vengeance I sustain;
490 Joyn Fraud to Force, and Policy to Pow'r;
491 'Till of the destin'd Fugitive secure,
492 In solemn State to Parricide I rise;
493 And, as GOD lives, this Day my Brother dies.
494 Be Witness to my Tears, Celestial Muse!
495 In vain I would forget, in vain excuse
496 Fraternal Blood by my Direction spilt;
497 In vain on Joab's Head transfer the Guilt:
498 The Deed was acted by the Subject's Hand;
499 The Sword was pointed by the King's Command.
500 Mine was the Murder: it was Mine alone;
501 Years of Contrition must the Crime attone:
502 Nor can my guilty Soul expect Relief,
503 But from a long Sincerity of Grief.
[Page 492]
504 With an imperfect Hand, and trembling Heart,
505 Her Love of Truth superior to her Art,
506 Already the reflecting Muse has trac'd
507 The mournful Figures of my Action past.
508 The pensive Goddess has already taught,
509 How vain is Hope, and how vexatious Thought;
510 From growing Childhood to declining Age,
511 How tedious ev'ry Step, how gloomy ev'ry Stage.
512 This Course of Vanity almost compleat,
513 Tir'd in the Field of Life, I hope Retreat
514 In the still Shades of Death: for Dread and Pain,
515 And Grief will find their Shafts elanc'd in vain,
516 And their Points broke, retorted from the Head,
517 Safe in the Grave, and free among the Dead.
518 Yet tell Me, frighted Reason! what is Death?
519 Blood only stopp'd, and interrupted Breath?
520 The utmost Limit of a narrow Span,
521 And End of Motion which with Life began?
522 As smoke that rises from the kindling Fires
523 Is seen this Moment, and the next expires:
524 As empty Clouds by rising Winds are tost,
525 Their fleeting Forms scarce sooner found than lost:
526 So vanishes our State: so pass our Days:
527 So Life but opens now, and now decays:
528 The Cradle and the Tomb, alas! so nigh;
529 To live is scarce distinguish'd from to dye.
[Page 493]
530 Cure of the Miser's Wish, and Coward's Fear,
531 Death only shews Us, what We knew was near.
532 With Courage therefore view the pointed Hour;
533 Dread not Death's Anger; but expect his Pow'r;
534 Nor Nature's Law with fruitless Sorrow mourn;
535 But dye, O Mortal Man! for Thou wast born.
536 Cautious thro' Doubt; by Want of Courage, Wise,
537 To such Advice, the Reas'ner still replies.
538 Yet measuring all the long continu'd Space,
539 Ev'ry successive Day's repeated Race,
540 Since Time first started from his pristin Goal,
541 'Till He had reach'd that Hour, wherein my Soul
542 Joyn'd to my Body swell'd the Womb; I was,
543 (At least I think so) Nothing: must I pass
544 Again to Nothing, when this vital Breath
545 Ceasing, consigns Me o'er to Rest, and Death?
546 Must the whole Man, amazing Thought! return
547 To the cold Marble, or contracted Urn?
548 And never shall those Particles agree,
549 That were in Life this Individual He?
550 But sever'd, must They join the general Mass,
551 Thro' other Forms, and Shapes ordain'd to pass;
552 Nor Thought nor Image kept of what He was?
553 Does the great Word that gave him Sense, ordain,
554 That Life shall never wake that Sense again?
555 And will no Pow'r his sinking Spirits save
556 From the dark Caves of Death, and Chambers of the Grave?
[Page 494]
557 Each Evening I behold the setting Sun
558 With down-ward Speed into the Ocean run:
559 Yet the same Light (pass but some fleeting Hours)
560 Exerts his Vigor, and renews his Pow'rs;
561 Starts the bright Race again: His constant Flame
562 Rises and sets, returning still the Same.
563 I mark the various Fury of the Winds:
564 These neither Seasons guide, nor Order binds:
565 They now dilate, and now contract their Force:
566 Various their Speed, but endless is their Course.
567 From his first Fountain and beginning Ouze,
568 Down to the Sea each Brook, and Torrent flows:
569 Tho' sundry Drops or leave, or swell the Stream;
570 The Whole still runs, with equal Pace, the Same.
571 Still other Waves supply the rising Urns;
572 And the eternal Floud no Want of Water mourns.
573 Why then must Man obey the sad Decree,
574 Which subjects neither Sun, nor Wind, nor Sea?
575 A Flow'r, that does with opening Morn arise,
576 And flourishing the Day, at Evening dyes;
577 A Winged Eastern Blast, just skimming o'er
578 The Ocean's Brow, and sinking on the Shore;
579 A Fire, whose Flames thro' crackling Stubble fly;
580 A Meteor shooting from the Summer Sky;
581 A Bowl a-down the bending Mountain roll'd;
582 A Bubble breaking, and a Fable told;
[Page 495]
583 A Noon-tide Shadow, and a Mid-night Dream;
584 Are Emblems, which with Semblance apt proclaim
585 Our Earthly Course: But, O my Soul! so fast
586 Must Life run off; and Death for ever last?
587 This dark Opinion, sure, is too confin'd:
588 Else whence this Hope, and Terror of the Mind?
589 Does Something still, and Somewhere yet remain,
590 Reward or Punishment, Delight or Pain?
591 Say: shall our Relicks second Birth receive?
592 Sleep We to wake, and only dye to live?
593 When the sad Wife has clos'd her Husband's Eyes,
594 And pierc'd the Echoing Vault with doleful Cries;
595 Lyes the pale Corps not yet entirely Dead?
596 The Spirit only from the Body fled,
597 The grosser Part of Heat and Motion void,
598 To be by Fire, or Worm, or Time destroy'd;
599 The Soul, immortal Substance, to remain,
600 Conscious of Joy, and capable of Pain?
601 And if Her Acts have been directed well,
602 While with her friendly Clay She deign'd to dwell;
603 Shall She with Safety reach her pristine Seat?
604 Find her Rest endless, and her Bliss compleat?
605 And while the buried Man We idly mourn;
606 Do Angels joy to see His better Half return?
607 But if She has deform'd this Earthly Life
608 With murd'rous Rapine, and seditious Strife;
609 Amaz'd, repuls'd, and by those Angels driv'n
610 From the AEtherial Seat, and blissful Heav'n,
[Page 496]
611 In everlasting Darkness must She lye,
612 Still more unhappy, that She cannot dye?
613 Amid Two Seas on One small Point of Land
614 Weary'd, uncertain, and amaz'd We stand:
615 On either Side our Thoughts incessant turn:
616 Forward We dread; and looking back We mourn.
617 Losing the Present in this dubious Hast;
618 And lost Our selves betwixt the Future, and the Past.
619 These cruel Doubts contending in my Breast,
620 My Reason stagg'ring, and my Hopes oppress'd,
621 Once more I said: once more I will enquire,
622 What is this little, agile, pervious Fire,
623 This flutt'ring Motion, which We call the Mind?
624 How does She act? and where is She confin'd?
625 Have We the Pow'r to guide Her, as We please?
626 Whence then those Evils, that obstruct our Ease?
627 We Happiness pursue; We fly from Pain;
628 Yet the Pursuit, and yet the Flight is vain:
629 And, while poor Nature labors to be blest,
630 By Day with Pleasure, and by Night with Rest;
631 Some stronger Pow'r eludes our sickly Will;
632 Dashes our rising Hope with certain Ill;
633 And makes Us with reflective Trouble see,
634 That all is destin'd, which We fancy free.
635 That Pow'r superior then, which rules our Mind,
636 Is His Decree by Human Pray'r inclin'd.
[Page 497]
637 Will He for Sacrifice our Sorrows ease?
638 And can our Tears reverse His firm Decrees?
639 Then let Religion aid, where Reason fails:
640 Throw loads of Incense in, to turn the Scales;
641 And let the silent Sanctuary show,
642 What from the babling Scholes We may not know,
643 How Man may shun, or bear his destin'd Part of Woe.
644 What shall amend, or what absolve our Fate?
645 Anxious We hover in a mediate State,
646 Betwixt Infinity and Nothing; Bounds,
647 Or boundless Terms, whose doubtful Sense confounds
648 Unequal Thought; whilst All We apprehend,
649 Is, that our Hopes must rise, our Sorrows end;
650 As our Creator deigns to be our Friend.
651 I said; ‚Äî and instant bad the Priests prepare
652 The ritual Sacrifice, and solemn Pray'r.
653 Select from vulgar Herds, with Garlands gay,
654 A hundred Bulls ascend the Sacred Way.
655 The artful Youth proceed to form the Choir;
656 They breath the Flute, or strike the vocal Wire.
657 The Maids in comely Order next advance;
658 They beat the Tymbrel, and instruct the Dance.
659 Follows the chosen Tribe from Levi sprung,
660 Chanting by just Return the Holy Song.
661 Along the Choir in Solemn State they past.
662 ‚Äî The Anxious King came last.
663 The Sacred Hymn perform'd, my promis'd Vow
664 I paid; and bowing at the Altar low,
[Page 498]
665 Father of Heav'n! I said, and Judge of Earth!
666 Whose Word call'd out this Universe to Birth;
667 By whose kind Pow'r and influencing Care
668 The various Creatures move, and live, and are;
669 But, ceasing once that Care; withdrawn that Pow'r;
670 They move (alas!) and live, and are no more:
671 Omni-scient Master, Omni-present King,
672 To Thee, to Thee, my last Distress I bring.
673 Thou, that can'st Still the Raging of the Seas,
674 Chain up the Winds, and bid the Tempests cease;
675 Redeem my ship-wreck'd Soul from raging Gusts
676 Of cruel Passion, and deceitful Lusts:
677 From Storms of Rage, and dang'rous Rocks of Pride,
678 Let Thy strong Hand this little Vessel guide
679 (It was Thy Hand that made it) thro' the Tide
680 Impetuous of this Life: let Thy Command
681 Direct my Course, and bring me safe to Land.
682 If, while this weary'd Flesh draws fleeting Breath,
683 Not satisfy'd with Life, afraid of Death,
684 It hap'ly be Thy Will, that I should know
685 Glimpse of Delight, or Pause from anxious Woe;
686 From Now, from instant Now, great Sire, dispell
687 The Clouds that press my Soul; from Now reveal
688 A gracious Beam of Light; from Now inspire
689 My Tongue to sing, my Hand to touch the Lyre:
690 My open'd Thought to joyous Prospects raise;
691 And, for Thy Mercy, let me sing Thy Praise.
[Page 499]
692 Or, if Thy Will ordains, I still shall wait
693 Some New Here-after, and a future State;
694 Permit me Strength, my Weight of Woe to bear;
695 And raise my Mind superior to my Care.
696 Let Me, howe'er unable to explain
697 The secret Lab'rynths of Thy Ways to Man,
698 With humble Zeal confess Thy awful Pow'r;
699 Still weeping Hope, and wond'ring still Adore.
700 So in my Conquest be Thy Might declar'd:
701 And, for Thy Justice, be Thy Name rever'd.
702 My Pray'r scarce ended, a stupendous Gloom
703 Darkens the Air; loud Thunder shakes the Dome:
704 To the beginning Miracle succeed
705 An awful Silence, and religious Dread.
706 Sudden breaks forth a more than common Day:
707 The sacred Wood, which on the Altar lay,
708 Untouch'd, unlighted glows ‚Äî
709 Ambrosial Odor, such as never flows
710 From Arab's Gum, or the Sabaean Rose,
711 Does round the Air evolving Scents diffuse:
712 The holy Ground is wet with Heav'nly Dews:
713 Celestial Music (such Jessides' Lyre,
714 Such Miriam's Timbrel would in vain require)
715 Strikes to my Thought thro' my admiring Ear,
716 With Ecstasy too fine, and Pleasure hard to bear.
717 And lo! what sees my ravish'd Eye? what feels
718 My wond'ring Soul? an opening Cloud reveals
719 An Heav'nly Form embody'd and array'd
720 With Robes of Light. I heard: the Angel said:
[Page 500]
721 Cease, Man of Woman born, to hope Relief
722 From daily Trouble, and continu'd Grief.
723 Thy Hope of Joy deliver to the Wind:
724 Suppress thy Passions; and prepare thy Mind.
725 Free and familiar with Misfortune grow:
726 Be us'd to Sorrow, and inur'd to Woe.
727 By weak'ning Toil, and hoary Age o'ercome,
728 See thy Decrease; and hasten to thy Tomb.
729 Leave to thy Children Tumult, Strife, and War,
730 Portions of Toil, and Legacies of Care.
731 Send the Successive Ills thro' Ages down;
732 And let each weeping Father tell his Son,
733 That deeper struck, and more distinctly griev'd,
734 He must augment the Sorrows He receiv'd.
735 The Child to whose Success thy Hope is bound,
736 E'er thou art scarce Interr'd, or he is Crown'd;
737 To Lust of Arbitrary Sway inclin'd,
738 (That cursed Poyson to the Prince's Mind!)
739 Shall from thy Dictates and his Duty rove,
740 And lose his great Defence, his People's Love.
741 Ill Counsell'd, Vanquish'd, Fugitive, Disgrac'd,
742 Shall mourn the Fame of Jacob's Strength effac'd.
743 Shall sigh, the King diminish'd, and the Crown
744 With lessen'd Rays descending to his Son.
745 Shall see the Wreaths, His Grandsire knew to reap
746 By active Toil, and Military Sweat,
747 Pining incline their sickly Leaves, and shed
748 Their falling Honors from His giddy Head.
[Page 501]
749 By Arms, or Pray'r unable to asswage
750 Domestic Horror, and intestine Rage,
751 Shall from the Victor, and the Vanquish'd fear,
752 From Israel's Arrow, and from Judah's Spear:
753 Shall cast his weary'd Limbs on Jordan's Floud,
754 By Brother's Arms disturb'd, and stain'd with Kindred-Blood.
755 Hence lab'ring Years shall weep their destin'd Race
756 Charg'd with ill Omens; sully'd with Disgrace.
757 Time by Necessity compell'd, shall go
758 Thro' Scenes of War, and Epocha's of Woe.
759 The Empire lessen'd in a parted Stream,
760 Shall lose it's Course ‚Äî
761 Indulge thy Tears: the Heathen shall blaspheme:
762 Judah shall fall, oppress'd by Grief and Shame;
763 And Men shall from her Ruins know her Fame.
764 New √Ügypts yet, and second Bonds remain,
765 A harsher Pharaoh, and a heavyer Chain.
766 Again obedient to a dire Command,
767 Thy Captive Sons shall leave the promis'd Land.
768 Their Name more low, their Servitude more vile,
769 Shall, on Euphrates' Bank, renew the Grief of Nile.
770 These pointed Spires that wound the ambient Sky
771 Inglorious Change! shall in Destruction lye
772 Low, levell'd with the Dust; their Heights unknown,
773 Or measur'd by their Ruin. Yonder Throne,
774 For lasting Glory built, design'd the Seat
775 Of Kings for ever blest, for ever great,
[Page 502]
776 Remov'd by the Invader's barb'rous Hand,
777 Shall grace his Triumph in a foreign Land.
778 The Tyrant shall demand yon' sacred Load
779 Of Gold and Vessels set a-part to GOD,
780 Then by vile Hands to common Use debas'd;
781 Shall send them flowing round his drunken Feast,
782 With sacrilegious Taunt, and impious Jest.
783 Twice fourteen Ages shall their Way complete:
784 Empires by various Turns shall rise and set;
785 While Thy abandon'd Tribes shall only know
786 A diff'rent Master, and a Change of Woe:
787 With down-cast Eye-lids, and with Looks a-ghast,
788 Shall dread the Future, or bewail the Past.
789 Afflicted Israel shall sit weeping down,
790 Fast by the Streams, where Babel's Waters run;
791 Their Harps upon the neighb'ring Willows hung,
792 Nor joyous Hymn encouraging their Tongue,
793 Nor chearful Dance their Feet; with Toil oppress'd,
794 Their weary'd Limbs aspiring but to Rest.
795 In the reflective Stream the sighing Bride,
796 Viewing her Charms impair'd, abash'd shall hide
797 Her pensive head; and in her languid Face
798 The Bridegroom shall fore-see his sickly Race:
799 While pond'rous Fetters vex their close Embrace.
800 With irksome Anguish then your Priests shall mourn
801 Their long-neglected Feasts despair'd Return,
802 And sad Oblivion of their solemn Days.
803 Thenceforth their Voices They shall only raise,
[Page 503]
804 Louder to weep. By Day your frighted Seers
805 Shall call for Fountains to express their Tears;
806 And wish their Eyes were Flouds: by Night from Dreams
807 Of opening Gulphs, black Storms, and raging Flames,
808 Starting amaz'd, shall to the People show
809 Emblems of Heav'nly Wrath, and Mystic Types of Woe.
810 The Captives, as their Tyrant shall require,
811 That They should breath the Song, and touch the Lyre,
812 Shall say: can Jacob's servile Race rejoice,
813 Untun'd the Music, and disus'd the Voice?
814 What can We play? (They shall discourse) how sing
815 In foreign Lands, and to a Barb'rous King?
816 We and our Fathers from our Childhood bred
817 To watch the cruel Victor's Eye, to dread
818 The arbitrary Lash, to bend, to grieve;
819 (Out-cast of Mortal Race!) can We conceive
820 Image of ought delightful, soft, or gay?
821 Alas! when We have toyl'd the longsome Day;
822 The fullest Bliss our Hearts aspire to know,
823 Is but some Interval from active Woe;
824 In broken Rest, and startling Sleep to mourn;
825 'Till Morn, the Tyrant, and the Scourge return.
826 Bred up in Grief, can Pleasure be our Theme?
827 Our endless Anguish does not Nature claim?
828 Reason, and Sorrow are to Us the Same.
829 Alas! with wild Amazement We require,
830 If Idle Folly was not Pleasure's Sire:
[Page 504]
831 Madness, We fancy, gave an Ill-tim'd Birth
832 To grinning Laughter, and to frantic Mirth.
833 This is the Series of perpetual Woe,
834 Which Thou, alas! and Thine are born to know.
835 Illustrious Wretch, repine not, nor reply:
836 View not, what Heav'n ordains, with Reason's Eye;
837 Too bright the Object is: the Distance is too high.
838 The Man who would resolve the Work of Fate,
839 May limit Number, and make Crooked Strait:
840 Stop Thy Enquiry then; and curb Thy Sense;
841 Nor let Dust argue with Omnipotence.
842 'Tis GOD who must dispose, and Man sustain,
843 Born to endure, forbidden to complain.
844 Thy Sum of Life must His Decrees fulfill:
845 What derogates from His Command, is Ill;
846 And that alone is Good, which centers in His Will.
847 Yet that thy Lab'ring Senses may not droop,
848 Lost to Delight, and destitute of Hope;
849 Remark what I, GOD's Messenger, aver
850 From Him, who neither can deceive, nor err.
851 The Land at length redeem'd, shall cease to mourn;
852 Shall from her sad Captivity return.
853 Sion shall raise her long-dejected Head;
854 And in her Courts the Law again be read.
855 Again the glorious Temple shall arise,
856 And with new Lustre pierce the neighb'ring Skies.
[Page 505]
857 The promis'd Seat of Empire shall again
858 Cover the Mountain, and command the Plain,
859 And from Thy Race distinguish'd, One shall spring,
860 Greater in Act than Victor, more than King
861 In Dignity and Pow'r, sent down from Heav'n,
862 To succour Earth. To Him, to Him 'tis giv'n,
863 Passion, and Care, and Anguish to destroy.
864 Thro' Him soft Peace, and Plenitude of Joy
865 Perpetual o'er the World redeem'd shall flow.
866 No more may Man inquire, nor Angel know.
867 Now, Solomon, rememb'ring Who thou art,
868 Act thro' thy remnant Life the decent Part.
869 Go forth: Be strong: With Patience, and with Care
870 Perform, and Suffer: To Thy self severe,
871 Gracious to Others, Thy Desires suppress'd,
872 Diffus'd Thy Virtues, First of Men, be Best.
873 Thy Sum of Duty let Two Words contain;
874 O may they graven in thy Heart remain!
875 Be Humble, and be Just. The Angel said:
876 With upward Speed His agile Wings He spread;
877 Whilst on the holy Ground I prostrate lay,
878 By various Doubts impell'd, or to obey,
879 Or to object: at length (my mournful Look
880 Heav'n-ward erect) determin'd, thus I spoke:
881 Supreme, Allwise, Eternal Potentate!
882 Sole Author, Sole Disposer of our Fate!
[Page 506]
883 Enthron'd in Light, and Immortality,
884 Whom no Man fully sees, and none can see!
885 Original of Beings! Pow'r Divine!
886 Since that I Live, and that I Think, is Thine;
887 Benign Creator, let Thy plastic Hand
888 Dispose it's own Effect. Let Thy Command
889 Restore, Great Father, Thy Instructed Son;
890 And in My Act may Thy great Will be done.

Editorial principles

The text has been typographically modernized, but without any silent modernization of spelling, capitalization, or punctuation. The source of the text is given and all editorial interventions have been recorded in textual notes. Based on the electronic text originally produced by the ECCO-TCP project, this text has been edited to conform to the recommendations found in Level 5 of the Best Practices for TEI in Libraries version 3.0.
